person.note: The inscription includes the formula εἱς θεός ἁ πάντων δεσπότης (one God who rules all). Despite claims that this formula is exclusively Christian, evidence of its use by Jews and Samritans is forthcoming (see Di-Segni, SCI 13 [1994] 94-115). The inscription is thus not specifically Christian. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.

This person is described as arguing a point of halakhah against a rabbi, and representing the other. Tropper, “Roman Contexts in Jewish Texts: On Diatagma and Prostagma in Rabbinic Literature,” JQR 95 (2005) 222-7.

Although he appears twice, only in BT, both appearances are within clear Palestinian midrashic traditions. This inscription was found in the theatre of Flavia Neapolis (Nablus). This theatre underwent architectural changes in the Byzantine period. The period this inscription represents is thus pre-Christian, at a time that most inhabitants of the city were Samaritans. He too could have been one, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.

Negev attampts to identify the Claudius mentioned in this inscription in order to date it, but his reasoning is circular. He identifies an epistrategos who served in Egypt in 203 but considers him too early. This assumption is repeated regarding another epistrategos of 241 and a prefect of Egypt from 246. However, since Claudius is the only means of dating the inscription, this claim is circular. In light of this information I would date the inscription to the 3rd century.

person.note: This is the story of his martyrdom. He describes himself as Πόλεως μέν εἰμι ἐγὼ Ναζαρε͂θ τῆς Γαλιλαίας , συγγένεια δὲ μοί έστιν πρὸς Χριστόν (I am from the city of Nazareth in Galilee and my relations are to Christ).

Other versions of the name are found in the mss to BT bHul98a, bBer55b and bBQ 82a, but they are all secondary, see 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4.

Tiberias was a city of mixed population and there is nothing specifically Jewish about this inscription, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.

div.note: Greek, WGE, 55. Alexander is another name Homer uses for the Tojan prince Paris (Ilias3:16). In S of S Rab 4:13 the name אלכסנדרי is interpreted as a popular transliteration of בנימין, but we have no concrete example to prove it.
Greek, WGE, 98. Antiochus was a name of Hellenistic monarchs, and the despised instigator of the 197 BCE decrees against Judaism.
